Optimizing Blade and Soul with Python: introduction

code
games
blade and soul
Published

March 29, 2025

Videogames are my biggest passion, and trying to play games in the best way possible is something I do whenever the occasion presents itself. For me, minmaxing is part of the fun.

That’s not to say that all games are made equal, and can be optimized in the same way. In some cases, “playing better” means “looking up guides online”, for others it may be a matter of “training my aim”. In a lot of cases, it’s a combination of multiple things.

What is this about?

In this series of blog posts I will be talking about how I have been trying to optimize how I play a specific game: a MMORPG called Blade & Soul NEO (aka BnS). While the game itself is almost 10 years old, a “Classic” version was released a few weeks ago. After clocking more than 4000 hours on the original version, I decided to give the revamp a try.

While the game itself has issues, its strong points are still there, and they got me hooked enough to get a bunch of ideas on how I could improve the attributes of my character by making use of things I learned during my studies and work. Added bonus, I could use this as an excuse for learning new stuff that could be useful later.

Among the things I’ve done/learned:

  • How to generate combinations of options with specific, strict constraints, and how to select the best
  • How to get equipment information out of the game when the game does not provide an API
  • How to write scripts for Google Sheets
  • How to get a proper formula to optimize for, and how to use it in my programs
  • How to plan a build by looking at how stats interact with each other.

So, maybe you’re interested in the game itself, or in how I used Python, Google Docs, and various AI tools to figure this out. Or maybe you’re just interested in the ramblings of a mad man that clearly has way too much time on his hands. In any case, please follow along and dive into the rabbit hole with me!

And a disclaimer: I am trying to reverse engineer what happens in-game, and trying to combine it with my own conclusions and posts I find online. I’m mostly having fun with this, and I don’t intend to claim that everything here is correct.

Now, the basics: how are character attributes assigned?

Like in many other games, character attributes (or stats) in Blade and Soul are given by a combination of base stats and additional stats. Base stats depend on the character’s class, level, and some other sources (such as achievements). Overall, base stats remain mostly constant after reaching a certain point. Additional stats are instead provided by a character’s equipment, and can be changed very easily simply by swapping different equipment pieces.

Equipment in BnS can be divided broadly in weapon and accessories, soulshield and badges. There are also insignias, but those are a bit different and will be covered in their own post. All other items can have one or more statistics, whose value will be added directly to the base stats of the character.

This earring, for example, has 40 Accuracy and 76 Critical Rate (and more stats, but let’s ignore them for now). By equipping it, the Accuracy and Critical Rate of my character will increase by 40 and 76 respectively.

The next, and most important source of stats is the Soulshield set, which will be the focus of the next post.

This soulshield gives HP (increasing how much damage my character can take), as well as Critical damage and Defense. It belongs to the Soulshield set “Horror’s Oath”, along with 4 more other pieces; since I have equipped 5 pieces, I also gain the additional Set effects, which further increase the statistics. In Blade and Soul, shields are always equipped as a set of 3, 5, or 8 pieces.

Each piece of equipment (or soulshield slice) is generated with a random set of statistics, and a random amount for each statistic. Finding equipment with the correct set of attributes and with the best possible rolls is how most of the time is spent while playing this game.

Damage in Blade and Soul: why and how

For this section I will be focusing only on the PvE (Player versus Environment) part of the game. In PvE, the objective is reducing the HP bar of the enemy bosses to 0 before they do the same to the player. In some cases, there is an enrage timer that will immediately kill the player if they take too long to kill the boss.

Typically, boss fights require players to use their skills in a way to maximize the damage they deal to the boss, while executing a set of mechanics at the same time (avoiding the boss’ attacks, activating items in the arena etc.). If a player is executing everything correctly, then better attributes lead to better damage. In general, having more damage makes fights easier by leaving more leeway and potentially avoiding specific mechanics.

Blade and Soul attributes can be either offensive or defensive. Defensive attributes reduce the damage taken from enemies in a variety of ways, and I will not go over them in this post. Offensive attributes include Attack Power (AP), Accuracy, Critical hit, and Critical damage.

The Attack Power is quite straightforward: all skills that deal damage have an “AP multiplier”, take the AP value and multiply it by a certain amount (e.g., 2.80AP). Both Critical hit and Critical damage apply another multiplier on top of the resulting AP, depending on whether or not a hit is a “crit” or not. I will be using a damage formula that was shared in the community, which goes as follows: \[ Damage = AP \times (Crit\% \times CDmg + (1-Crit\%)) \]

Here, \(Crit\%\) is the probability to land a “Critical hit”: a Critical hit deals additional damage equal to \(AP\times CDmg\). Since not all hits are critical hits, the “Damage” is given by the damage of critical hits weighted by how frequently they occur, in addition to the damage of hits that do not crit.

As an example, let’s consider \(AP=500\), \(Crit\%=55\%\), \(CDmg=150\%\): the equation would become \[ Damage = 500 \times (0.55 \times 1.5 + (1 - 0.55)) = 687.5 \] In a vacuum, a character with 687.5 AP and 0 \(Crit\%\) would deal the same damage as a character with the example stats described above. I am ignoring all sorts of interactions with critical hits for simplicity here. Clearly, better Crit% and CDmg would result in a larger value for Damage, and in practice to better DPS.

However, what we see on a character’s profile is the raw number of Critical hit and Critical damage. How can we turn those into the multipliers used above? Well, while there are no official numbers for this, the community managed to get an estimate of the formula, which is what I am using here: \[ Crit\% = \frac{Crit \times 96.98979}{Crit + 1124.069} \] where \(Crit\) is the Critical hit attribute. \[ CDmg = \frac{CD \times 290.8}{CD \times 2102.36} + 125 \] where \(CD\) is the Critical damage attribute.

I am using this as my source for those numbers.

So, this gave me a fairly rough estimate of how much damage my character can deal with a given amount of Critical hit and Critical damage. I stress that this estimate is not perfect for various reasons (e.g., some classes can buff their critical hit or critical damage via skills), but it’s still a good starting point to plan builds around.

To summarize

This was a lot! I’ll just summarize the main points and give an indication of where I’ll be going from here.

  1. I am trying to optimize the set of equipment I am using for my character in Blade and Soul.
  2. To do this, I need to find the best combination of accessories to maximize the attributes of my character.
  3. This is done in part by selecting the best combination of soulshields.
  4. I am trying to maximize the amount of damage and I can do so by improving my critical hit and critical damage attributes.
  5. I can use datamined formulas to estimate the damage amount, and use that as a metric to select the best set of equipment.

What next?

This was a very long-winded introduction to what I am hoping will become a series of posts. Some of the subjects I’d like to cover include:

  • Using the damage formulas to prepare a few figures to study and draw some preliminary conclusion from.
  • Writing some software that can select the best set of soulshields given a list of pieces.
  • Figuring out a reliable way of getting the soulshield statistics using Google sheets.
  • Re-implementing the code I wrote in Python using a different programming language as an exercise.

As I publish the new posts, I will add the appropriate links here.
